author: hikariws
content:
on smartcontracts that we store our money, like staking or L2, what procedure assures that only us and nobody else is able to withdraw our money?
blockchain-wise, is it possible to know how much money each address has staked on the sc?

author: hikariws
content: same thing regarding some games that require us to transfer our NFT to their smartcontract so we can play with them, is there risk of somebody else stealing our NFT, or the smartcontract denying sending them back when we ask?

author: treyzania
content: staking and L2s are very different beasts

author: treyzania
content: for L2s the smart contract enforces it

author: treyzania
content: but the smart contract is enforced by the consensus protocol

author: hikariws
content: I mean transfer resources to sc then borrow it back

author: treyzania
content: I'm not sure what you're asking then

author: hikariws
content: somebody lent 5 NFT to a game sc, how can we be sure that these NFT won't be stolen and the sc will deliver them back when requested?

author: treyzania
content: you can't, generally

author: treyzania
content: you would have to know how the smart contract works

author: hikariws
content: we must read its source?

author: treyzania
content: then the rules for getting sole ownership of the NFT back are dependent on the rules described by the smart contract

author: treyzania
content: so yes

author: hikariws
content: so the owner of the sc can change it and steal all resources stored on it?

author: treyzania
content: smart contracts don't have owners

author: treyzania
content: smart contracts once deployed are immutable

author: treyzania
content: but you can write a smart contract that allows certain accounts to modify its behavior, potentially by replacing its implementation

author: hikariws
content: I thought new versions could be deployed

author: hikariws
content: what happens if a sc has some bug?

author: treyzania
content: then you need to design the smart contract in such a way that the implementation can be swapped out in the future

author: treyzania
content: how this is decided is dependent on the smart contract

author: treyzania
content: you can have a governance token system where a user can propose an update and token holders vote on whether or not to accept it

author: treyzania
content: but *all* of that is visible on-chain

author: treyzania
content: it is possible to *know* with certainty how a contract will behave in the future

author: hikariws
content: and how is this swap/update done?

author: treyzania
content: it depends

author: treyzania
content: look up the "proxy contract pattern"

author: treyzania
content: updatable behavior is something that must be opted into when developing the contract system initially, by default contracts are immutable and cannot not modify their behavior

author: hikariws
content: interesting

author: hikariws
content: so we must trust the sc to lend resources to it but we can read it and see what it does with these resources?

author: jacknelson
content: yes

author: treyzania
content: you don't *have* to *trust* anything, you can read the code

author: treyzania
content: if there's a mechanism that allows a certain account to swap out the behavior without any delay then that's a red flag

author: treyzania
content: but if it *is* possible to swap out the behavior, it is possible to design these updatable systems in a way that users will have a grace period before an update can be applied

author: jacknelson
content: what is a standard grace period?

author: jacknelson
content: and im assuming in blocks right

author: treyzania
content: there is no standard, it's entirely dependent on the situation

author: treyzania
content: if it's something users are very involved with then that could be on the order of a day, for something more involved like a game that could be on the order of weeks/months

author: treyzania
content: if it's something like a game then it might be worthwhile to issue some governance token so users have to vote to accept an update, or vote to have an update applied sooner, but this could lead to bad incentives

author: hikariws
content: so if a bug is found and no block behavior exists then it can be exploited and nobody is able to stop it?

author: treyzania
content: yup

author: treyzania
content: which *is* a liability

author: treyzania
content: but it's also a strength, because it means that service providers can't just *decide* to change the rules on you

author: piku3141
content: Hopefully this is a decent place for this.  Is there any merit to the daggers that are thrown by Cardano folks about Casper?  Specifically that it isn't mathematically proven.  Those daggers were thrown in video a while ago so maybe that has changed.

author: potuz
content:
Have no clue about Cardano nor any daggers, also don't know what lack of proof they refer to. What ultimately got implemented in Ethereum is very different than the original Casper paper, but the Casper paper in particular contains a couple of theorems 
: Theorem 1 proving accountable safety and theorem 2 proving plausible liveness, that can be read by any highschool student. If they claim those two are wrong or not proved, then I'd suspect anything else they say

author: ajsutton
content: Also worth noting that the phase0 beacon chain spec has been formally verified.
